title: Thor's Taika Waititi on feeling 'worthless' as Adolf Hitler
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Taika Waititi has opened up on his immediate reaction to seeing himself as Adolf Hitler in Jojo Rabbit.

The Thor director wrote, directed and starred as infamous dictator Hitler who in this film is instead the bumbling imaginary friend of JoJo Bunny (Roman Griffin Davis), a lonely German boy who joins the Hitler Youth in Nazi Germany.

Dressed in the garb of the former German Chancellor, Waititi declined to shave his own moustache into the well-known Charlie Chaplin-esque mini-stache out of fear of what might happen if he went outside.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Still, the New Zealand filmmaker was unmistakably Hitler in the film that also stars Scarlett Johansson, Rebel Wilson and Sam Rockwell.

And seeing himself for the first time in the mirror as the character dredged up a lot of emotions.

‘Mainly I was embarrassed, it’s not a cool thing to dress up like that and you don’t feel cool when you’re dressed up like that,’ Waititi told Metro.co.uk at the BFI London Film Festival gala screening of his film.

He called the outfit ‘stupid’ (Picture: Splash News)

‘The moustache is ridiculous. I think only Chaplin managed to pull it off, then Hitler went and ruined it for everyone.

‘Then his hair cut is stupid. You look in the mirror and you’ve got the stupid getup on and you feel…the best word is worthless.’

He mock cried: ‘So it was really hard for me!’

Speaking of satirising Hitler but not making him accessible, because, you know atrocities, Waititi added he was careful in his approach of how he mastered the outfit.

‘I had to be very careful not to make the character loveable, or fun, or not to go “oooh I can’t wait to dress up in this stuff”. It’s not fun,’ he said.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘I had fun working with Roman and doing those scenes where I’m communicating with him and being an idiot, but there’s never a moment where I feel you should relish playing that role.’

The film also stars Scarlett as Jojo’s mum (Picture: Twentieth Century Fox)

Recently speaking at the Karlovy Vary International Film Festival, Waititi – who is set to start working on the fourth Thor film, Love And Thunder – said: ‘I play an imaginary friend who is sort of a kind of cross between Hitler and all this little boy’s heroes.

‘So it’s all kind of combined into this weird version of… it’s not Hitler, I’m not trying to play that character, so I didn’t do much research since I’m not trying to be authentic.’

The filmmaker previously revealed that years went by between writing JoJo Rabbit’s first scene and the film’s end cut.

Speaking at Bafta’s Screenwriters Lecture Series last year, he was asked how he finds returning to a script he had written years ago.

‘I’ve done that with all my films.’ he replied.

‘I’d say that most of them, apart from my first one, that was very fast in making that, the rest of them were at least five years between writing the first draft and making the film.’
